evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: For entry level positions it is a good place to get exposed to the necessary regulations and lending practices. Size of the company offers a wide range of fields to find a niche. Company culture is standard corporate but positive.
Cons: Promotion opportunities are very undefined. After entry level positions, the salary is extremely poor compared to Industry averages. As a non-revenue generating department, there is no incentive structure. Management keeps their heads down and will never give you the time of day. Zero employee loyalty. They will churn you out, burn you out, and then turn you out.
Advice to Management: Appreciate the people actually doing the work for you. That doesn’t just mean a luncheon or a jeans day. Actually take the time to get to know the people in your department. Value their opinions and encourage their growth.

Advice to Management: Mostly just keep doing what you've been doing. You navigated Wintrust through the 2008 disaster and you're seeing us through this pandemic. You're obviously doing a lot of things right.

Cons: Not great for someone that values dynamic work environments with changing process/improvements. Software was outdated. Management had a they vs them attitude. Limited opportunities for growth, not a great environment for someone that wants to move quickly and make a significant impact.

evaluation: Recommends, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: - Free Gym Membership - Free access to a bar - Employee Luncheons - An easy work environment to familiarize yourself in IT - Continually growing, easy to find jobs in the company - Perfect for a first job coming out of college - Working in a team environment, but allows you a lot of time to work by yourself too.
Cons: - A once relaxed working environment is turning stressful due to increasing restrictions from management. - Outdated and archaic policies and procedures hindering our ability to do our jobs effectively, solely to appease management. - No longer allowed to work remotely. Forced to come to the office Saturdays, staying for 8 hours, only to reset 1 password the entire day. - Too much downtime during the winter season with little work to do. You can go stircrazy.  - False promises of training. - Expected to do work outside of our scope. Yet, we still get reprehended for doing so. - Department morale at all time low. - An unreasonable expectations for perfection from management, as well as other departments.
Advice to Management: "People don't quit their jobs. They quit their bosses."

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: I really enjoyed the atmosphere at Wintrust. Everyone was very friendly and genuinely wanted to help one another. Being the intern, I felt like everyone spent time to help me learn and improve my skills. Also, you have the opportunity to learn about other job functions within the company. Although I was a data management intern, I was able to spend a few days in the Chicago office with the treasury management team. The internship was thought of as a learning experience and managers were very lenient on letting their interns experience other job functions within the bank.
Cons: Occasionally, there were days where I did not have much work to do. When this happened, I would just sit at my computer waiting for an email or a task I can do.
Advice to Management: Possibly assign a summer long project or presentation that the intern must finish by the end of the internship. This would give interns more work to do when they are finished with their every day work.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Close to public transportation and by the airport.
Cons: Wintrust Financial is a small bank trying to play IT with the big dogs in the industry. They lack vision on what is truly necessary to get them to a big bank status. They believe they can manage using technology at the cheapest cost to make things work. They have outdated software applications and lack the staff and resources to take this company to become a big bank with the customer benefits that come with it. The leadership is old school with a new CIO. You have to be part of the good ole boys club to provide any input while new ideas and technologies are shunned. The work/life balance leaves much to be desired with an old school mentality when it comes to dress code and work from home policy. Benefits aren't great and the software tools to support them are archaic. The left hand doesn't play well with the right hand.
Advice to Management: Be open to new ideas and technologies. Get in the trenches with the workers. The top down communication gets lost in translation. The status quo requires it to be challenged or things will not improve. It's not always about the bottom line in IT.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: The company is in a huge state of growth, so there is opportunity for someone with prior experience to come in and shape the company.  This relates to the cons, but a pro that has come out of the fact that Wintrust is so understaffed is that many have gotten the opportunity to work on many different systems and gain expertise in various areas of the technical department.
Cons: Management treats employees very poorly. No regard for employees well being - the bottom line is all that matters. My team works long hours, some of us working shifts both during the day and throughout the night.   The company is trying to operate like the other hard hitting banks, but we just don't have the staff or the resources to follow through. Many times processes will be put in place and initiatives will be started, but the company doesn't have the infrastructure or the man power to support it. This results in unstable applications and systems.  Management sets unrealistic deadlines that results in employees being overworked and results in deliverables that were completed the quick and dirty way instead of allowing employees the proper time on a project to get it done the right way.
Advice to Management: Treat your employees like human beings. We don't need to all be great friends, but respect in the workplace is seriously lacking.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO

Cons: New CIO has incorporated an outsourcing culture/model, which limits opportunities to learn new technologies and take on interesting projects, plethora of new faces looking to make names for themselves, chaotic IT environment, a lot of lip service, annoying monthly IT staff meetings filled with shallow leadership platitudes and grandstanding. evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO

Cons: Low pay increases, nepotism and favoritism run rampant, old school banking environment, stuffy, say they care about their employees, but it's not true (unless you're a family member or a favorite).

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: They have great products that make it easy to sell, no high presure sales goals.
Cons: The company is more focused on how much money they are making than they are on the work environment and work life balance provided to employees. Turnover is very high which makes it hard for the long term employees to do their jobs at times. The branches run on very lean staffs and when someone calls in it makes it hard on the entire retail staff. 401K is subpar and they only provide 12 weeks maternity leave and I don't believe it is paid at 100%. Decisions are being made at the corporate level that affect the retail banks and the people at corporate have no idea how the branches run or how those decisions may negatively impact the staff. Pay is lower than other retail banks.
Advice to Management: Before you hire people into the corporate world make them work in the retail banks so they can see how things run.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Great benefits. Great work/life ratio. They understand if you have to leave work if your kid gets sick at school. Left alone for the most part as long as the work gets done. You are expected to do a great job and aren't hounded, which I like.
Cons: Won't promote from within unless you came over in the PNC mass hiring wave that has over taken the company. Doesn't matter how good your reviews are you will be strung along with promises of promotion and raises that never happen regardless of meeting and exceeding their benchmarks year after year.
Advice to Management: Your worker bees who love their jobs are leaving en mass because you let the supervisors take credit for all of our work without giving us compensation. I'll never understand giving credit (and monetary reward) to the person who jumps in front of the parade and claims to be leading it. You allow us to be paid substandard rates but people are waking up and realizing their worth. 2% raises of an already underpaid salary aren't cutting it anymore.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Reasonable working hours Not too much micromanagement Conveniently located An office with great views Great coffee in the lobby, and a good gym nearby as well Not too many frivolous meetings
Cons: A generally apathetic and mildly to moderately discontent culture. Not quite dysfunctional enough to warrant one star, but still pretty bad. I imagine it's kind of like working for the DMV, except everyone you work with is a college graduate from a third tier institution (that's not to say every college graduate from a 3rd tier institutions is dumb though, as some are quite brilliant) .  Also, I can't speak to other peoples' experiences, but I felt totally out of place there. I also witnessed insane levels of turnover among the analysts, which doesn't speak well to the future viability of their investment product offerings.  Also, there was lots of middle management bloat.
Advice to Management: A wealth management company is not a bank. Stop treating it like one. Autocratic decision making, rigid hierarchy, a culture that rewards conventionality over originality, and so forth are the exact opposite traits that a company needs if it's going to produce superior investment results and provide high quality customer service.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Most of the people there are really friendly. There are very few egos walking around. You do not have to worry about only reporting to your boss. The rotational credit analyst program is a great tool for the start of a career. The bank is on the upward trend.
Cons: The money is not elite and senior management will say the culture here is better than going to chase money. While the rotational credit analyst program was very beneficial to me, the rotations and order of them were different for each analyst.
Advice to Management: Continue to offer a helping hand and lead by example. If someone is going to leave the bank, ask what you could have done differently to keep them there.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: The branch I work at is as employee oriented as it is customer oriented. We strive to be the best and help one another out whenever possible. Wintrust is doing better at learning to appreciate employees through awards and acknowedgement.  They do have good benefits and value a work/life balance.
Cons: I do not believe any of us are being justly compensated. We are given more responsibilities throughout the year and maybe given a small raise after the annual review. Job advancement is a bit rare.
Advice to Management: Figure out a way to financially compensate your employees better. Strive to help your employees find their potential and succeed. Motivation and teamwork are extremely helpful.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Independence and ability to work outside of job description. Excellent medical benefits.
Cons: Layers of bureaucracy have been added in recent years. Senior and longstanding employees have departed which has taken away from the employee focused culture that allowed Wintrust to attract and maintain talent. Morale was very low in 2016.
Advice to Management: The company has shifted from entrepreneurial core values to new standardized corporate values. The original values are still espoused; however, the impact has been felt. Many seasoned and original employees have left because of this. Wintrust can become Chicago's bank, but it has done so at the loss of many of it's founding family.

evaluation: NULL
Pros: I had been with the company for a while, the benefits are ok, the insurance has always been pretty good. They aren't cut throat on hitting goals like other big banks may be.
Cons: The company lacks organization, one day management tells you one thing the next day it has changed, this creates problems for the customers and the employees. Most of retail is underpaid and overworked, when someone leaves the position isn't reposted at times and the work just gets divided up between other employees, then they cap annual raises at 2.5%, 2.75% or 3% for the past few years. This is very demotivating. Work life balance is non existent. Most of the branches are understaffed with 3 tellers total working for the bank, this creates bad customer service, everyone is in a hurry to get rid of their customer so they can move onto the next task.
Advice to Management: Hire more people and spend more money, show the staff that they are appreciated by paying them more. The customer service would improve if there were more tellers/bankers to service the customers.

evaluation: Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Great opportunities for advancement. Highly regarded company within their market. Cash rich which allows one to cater to customers better than they would be able to otherwise. Very flexible with your vacation schedules and family time. Pay is within the normal range.
Cons: The company is very top heavy with a lot of SVP and higher employees and much fewer worker bees causing everyone to be hectic at all times. The company is very inefficient with its fifteen charters and I have yet to see a benefit to all the small banks. Their continued purchases of failed banks and cutting 80% + of their employees has caused many departments to be overworked and slow.
Advice to Management: Collapse some of the charters to improve efficiency. Slow down and ensure that every department has sufficient support staff and competent management to accomplish goals.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Excellent people and training. The Company is growing quickly and there is ample opportunities to learn.
Cons: Salary below market. Disconnect with senior management.
Advice to Management: Provide internal raises and better evaluations, especially to those with less experience and fewer years in the industry. An excellent credit training program, but since you're educating general human capital, must ensure employees are properly compensated. Otherwise they will have an incentive to move taking the education you gave them.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Great people  Great overall skill improvement opportunities  Growing corporation  Good benefits   Computer based training courses available to further technical education on personal time
Cons: Senior management lacks a clear understanding on employee staffing levels  Technology systems delivered lacks imagination and innovation  No formal training provided for on-boarding employees  Little room for professional advancement

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: I loved my team and customers, Wintrust is a community bank with big bank technology.
Cons: Old s  Life crisis such as a death were not given the proper respect that should have been given.
Advice to Management: Senior management needs to interact with middle management more to get to know their management team. LISTENING to other manager's especially a manager with controlling addiction could be costly. Especially when they are protecting their own position.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Good benefits and culture. Company for the most part values its employees and works to retain the people who perform.
Cons: Culture is changing as the company is growing. Flat management structure requires leadership to wear multiple hats and continually adapt to new challenges.
Advice to Management: Stay focused on the quality of the people and ensure that management ranks are not spread too thin. Watch for understaffed areas as the company continues to grow.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Plenty of opportunities to advance or change positions. Since there are 15 banks, if no opportunities are open at one bank, something will probably come up at another bank.
Cons: There seems to be some political maneuvering at headquarters--some people trying to make names for themselves without taking ownership of their actions (or lack of action).
Advice to Management: Before asking banks to staff themselves leaner, look at Rosemont's productivity.

evaluation: Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: The company culture is friendly and welcoming. There are many people to network with to help build your career. There is plenty of job security.
Cons: HR can be less than helpful and disorganized; they typically need to be asked to do their job (not all HR employees). The pay could be better and the annual raises for hourly employees are a joke. Computer systems are mostly outdated and the 15-charter, one-bank model makes it difficult to handle all customers efficiently.
Advice to Management: Invest in employee retention and take employee advice/concerns seriously. Many employees would be willing to take the same job somewhere else for better pay. Work with employees to develop a career plan and a path for growth so no one feels stuck in their position.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: They had free coffee... so there's that.
Cons: The pay is lower than at other banks, and the working conditions are also worse. The manager at my branch was a psycho who would scream at me until he was red in the face for things I didn't do. The supervisor was extremely rude, both to employees and to customers. I wound up quitting in four months after finding a better paying position at another bank. So, in all, it's pretty terrible.
Advice to Management: Don't scream at people? Learn to act like adults? Honestly the management at this place is so far gone there's no advice I could give. To be fair, I only had experience with the management at one retail bank location, so maybe I shouldn't tar the whole corporation. But any place willing to countenance the sort of behavior I saw has to be viewed with a lot of suspicion.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: I would say above avg health benefits, on-site gym at corp hq, good work-life balance. Company is still small to be nimble but big enough to make positive impact in the Chicago banking footprint. Overall nice employees to work with. Decent annual bonuses.
Cons: Top heavy organization with lots senor mgrs. Corp communications is probably the biggest cons as sr mgrs doesn't pass down goals, direction to middle and lower level analysts. I.e. the left hand doesn't talk to the right hand. Lack of remote access from home. Merit increases usually small, below industry avgs.
Advice to Management: Do evaluation of senior managers, make more employees accountable for their actions.

evaluation: Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Good exposure to commercial banking, given a variety of different types of project to work on, they were very helpful with advising me on what to put on my resume/talk about in interviews at the end of the internship.
Cons: Times where we didn't have any work to be done, somewhat hard to get in touch with certain people to ask questions.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Employee centric and really support work/life balance. Committed to the communities they operate in and give back in meaningful ways. They are a team that works well across all disciplines to support customers and employees.
Cons: Nothing material - lack of formal processes and coaching in some areas can make it difficult to navigate but it's workable.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook
Pros: - Great group of people, very genuine - Hours weren't very strict, and workload was always pretty consistent but not overwhelming - Solid pay and benefits Great and convenient location
Cons: - Intern work could be monotonous, but that comes with the name. - Wasn't a lot of structure in the intern program.
Advice to Management: Define the program a bit better, otherwise it's fine.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: The people are nice and willing to show you the ropes. Good work/life balance. Great benefits such as health, retirement, etc.
Cons: Vacation time is low but probably par for the course in the banking world. Different departments of the commercial bank are located in far suburban areas and not very centralized. Pay could be a bit better.

evaluation: Approves of CEO
Pros: Wintrust professionals are up to bar among their peers and always look out for the customer, sometimes even more than the company.
Cons: Lack of growth opportunities; poor communication; very traditional.
Advice to Management: Young professionals need more incentive to stay at the company.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Solid reputation. Stable work environment. Entrepreneurial culture. Many opportunities for cross-functional experience. Excellent medical benefits.
Cons: Tenure can trump performance. Senior level task-focused management. Infrastructure did not match company growth. Dated systems.
Advice to Management: Replace reactionary senior level managers with more strategic, forward-thinking, coaches.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: You can meet some great people. Great building location, lots to do during lunch or after work. Really good restaurants in the area.
Cons: Zero workplace flexibility and no work/life balance. You are expected to be in the office 8am-10pm. Upper management will openly bully talented employees just because they don't like them. No emphasis on career development.
Advice to Management: Stop cultivating a toxic environment. Inspire all employees and take an interest in employee development.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: great work-home life understanding, management actually cares for you as an individual, decent benefits, decent ways to advance
Cons: location of the corporate office
Advice to Management: Continue to understand the employee as an individual with a home life to balance as well as work

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Disapproves of CEO
Pros: Wintrust financial allows each bank president to tailor the loan and deposit products to meet the needs of the community it serves. Some of the banks have a strong following in the community and devoted employees to ensure the highest level of customer satisfaction. The bank president has the authority to run the charter as his/her own business which allows for an entreprenureal spirt only found in a start up bank. The employee benefits package is very generous and competes strongly with employers of similar industries. The bank is large enough (when one considers all charters as one) to compete with the larger banks in the area; this eliminates many of the objections when working with customers who are concerned about moving to a community bank.
Cons: The communication and sharing of information between the banks is extreamly limited. The leadership from the holding company does not trickle down to the bank level. Accountability for the banks performance is only judged on a profitability basis and does not incorporate employee turnover or customer satisfaction. It does not appear bank presidents of less profitable charters are held accountable for thier performance and poor performance is allowed to continue year over year. Senior management is a good old boys club made up from the original people who started the bank, no room for new ideas or opinions in this environment. The lack of diversity within the organization is concerning and does not promote opportunities for women or people of color.
Advice to Management: Holding company officials need to be more involved at the bank level to ensure that the bank president is providing the leadership and communication to carry out the organizations goals and inititatives. Improvment in information sharing and communication between the banks would reduce lost productivity. Having an operations staff at each charter is a large duplication of job function with little financial return for the redundancy which is also complicated by the vast diferences in knowledge and expierience of similar positions at each bank charter. Leadership training for all senior managment and some type of oversight would better improve the level of bank presidents at each location.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Fellow employees are very friendly and willing to assist.
Cons: Very nit picky about everything from what you wear to how you even speak to various individuals. Training is extremely weak and the leadership would rather cut an employee than invest in their future by providing proper training to do the job given.
Advice to Management: Properly train all employees to do their job well. Do not leave employees to be trained via proxy and over e-mail. Place all employees with someone who can provide them the training they need, not in an office 30 miles away and expect them to commute constantly for assistance.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Good benefits. Have on-site gym equipped with fitness classes for all employees free of charge. Two week vacation and unlimited sick days. Provides 401k match, medical (BCBS IL), dental and vision insurance. Discounts for AT&T, Jos A. Banks, etc.
Cons: Communication within departments is limited. A lot of micro managing. In order to fit in you must have a traditional mindset. Not very open to new ideas. Very cut throat environment. Not a team environment.
Advice to Management: Need to offer work/life balance. Offer remote access to all employees to allow all departments to remain functional and allow for work/life balance.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook
Pros: The allowed me to go into meetings and work with other section of the bank.
Cons: Not so much structure. Had to find work to do on the job sometimes.

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO
Pros: Opportunities and more coming up as we continue to grow
Cons: As with any place too much Politics
Advice to Management: Listen to your front line employees...don't make decisions in a vacuum

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: The salary is competitive within the field
Cons: Technology is far behind competitors, management is petty and unaccommodating, doesn’t tell you about expected community work.
Advice to Management: If technology (internet speed, efficiency in completing transactions, less flawed teller system, etc.) was upgraded just a bit, I would enjoy this job more and I’m sure you would be able to accumulate better talent. My previous bank was a “follower” when it comes to technology within the field, yet they were vastly more advance than our current systems.

evaluation: Recommends, Neutral Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

Advice to Management: Your company has seen great growth but it seems like those that are new to the company benefit greatly relative to those that laid the foundation. My suggestion would be to treat those that got you there appropriately but I feel this would fall on deaf ears.

evaluation: Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
Pros: Good benefits, free gym in building, free shuttle service to/from blue line, flexible scheduling, coffee/snacks, happy hours and team outings.
Cons: Very poor communication, which creates more unnecessary hearsay/gossip. Hard to advance, no room to learn/grow. Lack of teamwork. There is extreme favoritism. Seems like they are more interested in 'looking' the part verses actually streamlining and creating an efficient workflow environment. Behind the times technology wise.   uptight culture for a marketing dept. and below average pay
Advice to Management: Communication in the dept. is key, believe in your employees and help them feel part of a team. Everyone has their part and is important to the overall outcome.

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, Disapproves of CEO

Advice to Management: Treat your employees better, create better opportunities for them to advance within the department/company, create more engaging work for employees to stick around, pay higher salaries

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Negative Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Positive Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO

evaluation: No opinion of CEO

evaluation: Recommends, Positive Outlook, Approves of CEO

evaluation: Doesn't Recommend, Neutral Outlook, No opinion of CEO
